text: We will hear arguments next in Number 5038, Adams against Illinois.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

We will only test that in a moment, suppose the acts are witnessed by great many people and at a preliminary hearing they bring in two witnesses that are said to be typical of nine others except for discovery purposes, what would be done at the preliminary hearing?
Mr. Chief Justice, at the preliminary hearing those two witnesses would be cross-examined.
If -- it is discovery now.
No.
But if you are using it to prepare for trial, you are using it for discovery, are you not?
Well, you are using it also if it please the Court for impeachment because those statements used or fastening an impeachment tools would be used later on.
So, that is still discovery, is it not, preparing for trial?

Coleman in its determination of the values of a preliminary hearing differs between the fashioning of impeachment tools through the use of prior -- through the use of the prior statements at trial and discovery.
Was the Illinois statute not familiar with the details or its history.
The Illinois statute relative to preliminary hearings?
Yes.
No.
May the prosecutor under Illinois statutes bypass the preliminary hearing by giving an indictment or issuing an information if you use that process?
The indictment procedure in Illinois Mr. Chief Justice, but at that time they no longer can.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
Well, Mr. Gildea, are you not arguing the Coleman case now and we are -- that is behind this?
Yes Your Honor.
I thought the issue in this case was just, whether Coleman was to be retroactive?
That is correct Your Honor.
The sentence you are saying that nothing can be accomplished, why do lawyers retain counsel, a waste of time at preliminary hearings?
Well, it was not my intention to say that nothing can be accomplished.
Why, if you admit that something could be accomplished then where are you with solving this?
Well, something can be accomplished but something could also have been accomplished in Miranda, something could also have been accomplished in Wade and Gilbert and --
You have only got Coleman there.
That is correct but in the resolution of -- whether or not this substantially affects a subsequent trial.
Well, would not the presence of counsel increase the truth finding process?
That would be I think a -- the very least it could do is just speculation.
You do not think that defense counsel do its cross-examination that aid the truth finding factor.
I think there is the possibility it could.
Have you not read Law Review Articles of famous criminal lawyer said they would never waive a preliminary hearing under any circumstances.
Well, it is not a question of waiving a preliminary hearing.
What is the difference between waiving the preliminary hand and being there without counsel?
The question is what will a counsel do at a preliminary hearing?
Well, he will cross-examine, is it not?
He will cross-examine, yes Your Honor.
Because he has not got a thing in the world to loose.
That is correct.
So he will cross-examine.
That is correct.
Is that not helpful to the truth finding?
Yes.
Only in Illinois?

He has the right to interview witnesses, he gets to -- he has a right under his pretrial motions to a list of witnesses, he can ascertain the identities of the witnesses and he can talk to the witnesses.
Can he cross-examine them under oath?
No, he cannot Your Honor.
Just briefly speaking and may it please the Court.
